key: _gpt-5__How does the effectiveness of public education campaigns for bat conservation vary between continents?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of educating the public to improve the perception of bats.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of educating the public to improve behaviour towards bats.
[Statement 3]: The effectiveness of public education on bats could not be assessed.
[Statement 4]: Any variation in the effectiveness of public education on bats between continents could not be assessed.

[Statement 1]: Evidence on artificial bat roost creation reports outcomes but does not provide cost-effectiveness data.
[Statement 2]: Providing bat boxes, bat grilles, or roost improvements has no captured evidence for effects on farmland wildlife.
[Statement 3]: A before-and-after study in Spain found more bats in two artificial roosts after reducing the roosts' internal temperatures.
[Statement 4]: In the UK, heated bat boxes were used by common pipistrelles at one of seven sites.
[Statement 5]: Heated bat boxes in the UK were not used by maternity colonies.
[Statement 6]: None of twelve heated boxes in churches were used by displaced Natterer’s bats.
[Statement 7]: A UK study found bat numbers using an artificial hibernaculum increased in each of nine years after construction of the hibernaculum.
[Statement 8]: Another UK study recorded use of an artificial cave by a small number of brown long-eared bats.
[Statement 9]: Studies in Germany and the UK recorded use of artificial hibernacula by up to four bat species.
[Statement 10]: Two replicated studies in the USA and UK found no use of provided bat houses or a purpose-built bat wall after bat exclusion.
[Statement 11]: Other studies or reviews reported bat boxes or bat lofts/barns were used at 13–74% of sites.
[Statement 12]: Maternity use of bat boxes or bat lofts/barns was reported at one of 19 sites.
[Statement 13]: Three out of five before-and-after studies reported similar or higher use of purpose-built roosts after original roosts were destroyed.
[Statement 14]: Two out of five before-and-after studies reported lower use of purpose-built roosts after original roosts were destroyed.
[Statement 15]: A UK review found replacement roosts were four times less likely to be used than roosts retained during development.
[Statement 16]: A USA review found that spaces created in road bridges were recolonized by bats in similar or greater numbers than original roosts at four of eight sites.
